posts.name: Beckett | 6925 Alum + Onlooker (I promised to not mentor but I'm really nosy)
posts.cooked:
Hello,

What type of wood do you use as bumper wood? At our 2023 offseason competition, GRITS, our wood screws that we use to attach our bumper brackets to our bumpers were torn out of the wood very easily and we were disabled twice. For context, we use 4 separate reversible bumpers and plan to continue using them in 2024. Our total bumper weight was 11 pounds so we could increase if needed.
posts.display_username: Beckett | 6925 Alum + Onlooker (I promised to not mentor but I'm really nosy)

posts.cooked: https://www.woodworkerssource.com/plywood-sheet-goods/baltic-birch-plywood.html

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: In my experience, wood screws don’t hold well in any sort of bumper application – regardless of the quality of the wood.  I recommend thru-bolting with machine screws and nuts.

Baltic birch is my wood of choice and as many plys as I can find would be my reccomendation.

That alone may not be enough to keep wood screws from tearing out.  I recommend using some bolting solution that has a nut on the back side of the bumper that has to pull through.  We usually us T-Nuts that nail into the bumper to attach our brackets and we have found they hold up pretty well to contact.  (Remember to keep any bolt or nut no more than 1" outside of the frame perimeter, so only like 1/4" outside the plywood to stay within the current rules)

I would recommend using the T nuts to permanently attach your mounting hardware and do not use T-nuts as the way to attach and remove your bumpers or you will be sad when they start spinning and you can not take your bumpers off without pulling off fabric.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
Baltic / Russian Birch is best (the one with like 13 plies, used for good furniture), but I would recommend changing your design if you can.   A small number of short wood screws is never going to hold a bumper on to an FRC frame for very long.  Consider using something like:

a carriage bolt all the way through the plywood from the back, or

a tee nut insert from the back, or

a sheet metal bracket with dozens of wood screw holes .

posts.name: Joseph Barry
posts.cooked: Agree with Joel’s suggestion. You can also use something like 10-32 screws that pass through the bracket and plywood, with washer and locknuts on the outer side of the bumper wood to avoid the typical wood screws pulling out of whatever wood you select. Just be sure that the nuts remain within the 1" limit for hard parts outward from the inside of the bumper wood. Rules allow for you to cut a recess in the wood for the washer and nut if needed.

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked:

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
3/4"  (I think it’s nominal 4/4) hard maple that I happened to have in my garage.   Worked really well.

We’ve done reversible bumpers in the past but decided to just do two sets this past season.   All the sewing required for reversible bumpers and dealing with the velcro is a pain.

For attaching, short pieces of 1x1 angle aluminum permanently screwed into the wood, with a 2.5"  1/4" screw through the sides of our chassis into holes drilled into the aluminum.  (Easier to line up the angle precisely and THEN screw it into the wood.

We’ve tried T-nuts and they are a a royal PITA.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
This year I’m thinking teak, because, you know, water game.

Seriously though, we just use 1x6 solid pine, 10 wood screws & a quality wood glue.

posts.name: The Imagery Queen
posts.cooked: I think the best type of bumper wood depends on if you are going for lighter or heavier bumpers. One year, we purposefully made our bumpers out of heavier wood for mechanism reasons. If more concerned about sturdiness, the recommendations people make above are pretty good.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: We’ve been using 1x6 (cut down to 5" wide) poplar boards for years now. It’s a lighter hardwood, very durable, easy to work and join, but able to hold hardware like screws much better than most softwoods or than plywood (even Baltic birch.) It’s also readily available at any home store, hardware store, or lumber yard and not too expensive. We use 3/4" no.12 wood screws to attach our bumper brackets and they’ve never come out. To join the corners we cut finger joints with the CNC, then glue and screw (with appropriate pilot holes, of course) to ensure a solid joint. If you’re using a hardwood like poplar, that kind of corner works fine, something that isn’t nearly so easy in plywood of any kind.

posts.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826
posts.cooked:
If you use T-nuts I have a couple of suggestions.  Ban any use of impact drivers for that rapid change Nascar in the pits feelin’.  You can spin the T-nut and then you are in for it.  To that end I’d also suggest that you put teeny little wood screws into the notches of the T-nut to further reduce the chance of a spin.

We’ve moved away from using them but there are a dozen viable options, all of which you’ll hear about in great detail on CD!
posts.display_username: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
tjwolter:

If you use T-nuts I have a couple of suggestions. Ban any use of impact drivers for that rapid change Nascar in the pits feelin’. You can spin the T-nut and then you are in for it.

This year we are very seriously looking at 2910’s bumper style.  They used T-nuts to fasten a 1x1 aluminum tube to the wood, but those fasteners (in an ideal season) are never touched again.  A separate set of captive bolts are used to fasten the 1x1 to the robot frame.

posts.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826
posts.cooked: Here’s what we used.  The section of 80/20 is securely bolted onto the frame with nylock and lock washer.  A detent pin goes through it.  It is held in by a hair band supplied by the creator of this system, which we call Hallie Clips in her honor.  There are long 90 degree brackets attached to the bumper wood with plenty of wood screws.  This plus snug fitting bumpers and some substantial corner braces made a very secure and quick changing solution.  Pull out the four detent pins and lift it off.
posts.display_username: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
It is very hard to get screws to pull out of baltic birch. Don’t try to get your birch ply at a regular home improvement store, it will be very thin birch veneers on a softwood core like any other cabinet grade plywood. If you find yourself and a specialty lumber yard for the Baltic birch you may also be able to get bs-1088 marine plywood with is even stronger and comes in 4x8 sheets instead of 5x5.

I’d advise against solid wood, 1x6s are only legal if they are at or below the 5.5” spec, so humidity could cause your bumpers to become illegal. Softwoods will also be weaker than plywood. Hardwoods seem like overkill for no real benefit unless you’re messing with densities.

posts.name: Nemo
posts.cooked: We prefer the unusually dense maple from the Little Ice Age. Since that wood is no longer available, our team purchases 17th century violins and makes them into bumper plywood.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Patrick3357:

Softwoods will also be weaker than plywood.

It’s not clear to me that the wood is what really matters.  We took this full-speed head on collision which not only put a fairly impressive kink in our frame, but also destroyed all 5 of these clips McMaster-Carr that were holding the bumper-half on.

The wood is as good as new.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: You could pick/make bad wood planks for bumpers and some wood is easier to work with but having your frame properly supported is more important than what tree your wood was made from, when dealing with hits like that.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: How did you mount the 80/20?  I wanted to this last year but couldn’t think of a good way to mount the 80/20.

reply_to_user.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826

posts.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826
posts.cooked: Well, the frame is 1 by 2 box with hardwood inserts.  Drill though a couple of quarter inch holes north to south.  Generally T-fasteners can be counted on to vibrate loose, but if you thread them onto a high grade bolt which has a lock washer or two on the underside, then crank 'em good and tight, the piece of 80/20 will not go anywhere.  The detent pin of course goes through the small central hole of the 80/20.  We also have triangular blocks on each corner of the frame so that downward force is not an issue and to make neat alignment much easier.  We custom laser up the L brackets.  Make them long enough to get three or four hefty wood screws in there.  Gave us no problems during two events and is as quick a change as you’ll find.
